Class DateUtil

extends Object
    utilities for handling date

    • Method Detail

      • daysBetweenDates

        public static int daysBetweenDates(long toDate,
                                   long fromDate)
        number of days between two dates. time part is ignored from both dates. If you want to consider time as well, then use elapsedDaysBetweenDates()
        Parameters:
        toDate - milli-second representation of to-date. By convention, this should be a UTC date for 0:00 AM
        fromDate - milli-second representation of from-date. By convention, this should be a UTC date for 0:00 AM
        Returns:
        number of days as counted from date to date, and not based on 24 hours of elapsed time time.

      • daysFromToday

        public static int daysFromToday(long toDate)
        number of days the supplied date is from today in the future. same as date - today.
        Parameters:
        toDate - note that this is long - date in milliseconds (date.getTime())
        Returns:
        number of days as counted from today forward into toDate. If toDate is the past, returned value is -ve.

      • elapsedDaysBetweenDates

        public static int elapsedDaysBetweenDates(long toTime,
                                          long fromTime)
        number of elapsed days (completed 24 hours) between two specific time intervals.
        Parameters:
        toTime - note that this is long - date in milliseconds (date.getTime())
        fromTime - note that this is long - date in milliseconds (date.getTime())
        Returns:
        number of days counted as 1 for every 24 hours from startDate = toDate - fromDate

      • elapsedDaysBetweenDates

        public static int elapsedDaysBetweenDates(Date toDate,
                                          Date fromDate)
        number of elapsed days (completed 24 hours) between two specific time intervals.
        Parameters:
        toDate -
        fromDate -
        Returns:
        number of days counted as 1 for every 24 hours from startDate = toDate - fromDate

      • trimDate

        public static long trimDate(long date)
        chop milliseconds from this date, as per default calendar
        Parameters:
        date - milli seconds in this date
        Returns:
        milli seconds that correspond to date with no time

      • getToday

        public static Date getToday()
        Get today's date as per local calendar.
        Returns:
        a date object that represents a UTC date that is equal to today in local calendar. for example, if local calendar says 20-Aug-2016, but UTC would say 21-Aug-2016, this function returns date that would print in UTC as '2016-08-20T00:00:00.000Z'

      • parseDate

        Parameters:

        Returns:
        date or null if it is not a valid date

        Parameters:

        Returns:

      • format

        public static String format(Date date)
        format date into text, in an economic way. If this is pure date with no time, format it as date, else format it is UTC date-time. Use this ONLY if it suits you to have a shorter version if possible. If you need the output to be in a predictable format, use formatDate() or formatDateTime()
        Parameters:
        date - may be date may be date and time, and we do
        Returns:
        text

      • format

        public static String format(long date)
        format date into text, in an economic way. If this is pure date with no time, format it as date, else format it is UTC date-time. Use this ONLY if it suits you to have a shorter version if possible. If you need the output to be in a predictable format, use formatDate() or formatDateTime()
        Parameters:
        date - may be date may be date and time, and we do
        Returns:
        text

      • hasTime

        public static boolean hasTime(Date date)
        is this date a pure date, or has it got time component? It is dangerous to guess this in your logic, as it is perfectly possible that the date-time field may actually happen exactly at that time. Your algorithm should KNOW whether the date in question represents a pure date or it date-time. This function is to be used for formatting where such a possible error does not cause the algorithm to fail (For example for display purposes)
        Parameters:
        date -
        Returns:
        true if this has time component, false otherwise

      • hasTime

        public static boolean hasTime(long value)
        is this date a pure date, or has it got time component? It is dangerous to guess this in your logic, as it is perfectly possible that the date-time field may actually happen exactly at that time. Your algorithm should KNOW whether the date in question represents a pure date or it date-time. This function is to be used for formatting where such a possible error does not cause the algorithm to fail (For example for display purposes)
        Parameters:
        value -
        Returns:
        true if there is time of the day, false if it is a pure date
